item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic's Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: PCA Analysis of Climate Variables
item.description:
Introduction

Environmental and climatic factors of 243 countries were compiled by @zander_venter on Kaggle through Google Earth and public remote sensing data. This analysis looks to examine the multivariate relationship between climatological and land use factors inlcuding accessibility to cities, elevation, cropland cover, tree canopy cover, mean temperature, mean rainfall, and cloudiness for countries listed as having greater than 50% cropland cover. In the following principle components analysis, the relationshiop between these factors and their correlation is explored (Figure 1).

Necessary packages for this analysis include: tidyverse, janitor, and ggfortify. All data analysis and visualization was produced using RStudio Version 1.2.1335

PCA Analysis

# Read in data

variables <- read_csv("world_env_vars.csv") %>% 
  clean_names() 

# Wrangle data to filter countries with greater than 50.0 cropland_cover metrics
# Select climate related variables as well as land use variables including accessibility_to_cities, elevation, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, temp_mean_annual, rain_mean_annual, and cloudiness
# Remove observations, if any, that have 'na' values for any variable(s)

variables_sub <- variables %>% 
  filter(cropland_cover > 50.0) %>% 
  select(accessibility_to_cities, elevation, cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, temp_mean_annual, rain_mean_annual, cloudiness) %>% 
  drop_na()

# Create primary components analysis 

my_pca <- prcomp(variables_sub, scale = TRUE)

# View PCA
#my_pca      #(uncheck to see compenenet eigenvalues/eigenvectors)

# Create biplot using PCA created above

my_biplot <- autoplot(my_pca,
                      colour = NA, 
                      loadings.label = TRUE,
                      loadings.label.size = 3,
                      loadings.label.colour = "black",
                      loadings.label.repel = TRUE) +
  theme_bw() +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(-.35, 0.3)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0)) +
  labs(title = "Principle components analysis plot of climate and land-use variables",
       x = "Principle Component 1 (34.48%)",
       y = "Principle Component 2 (26.69%)")

# View biplot
my_biplot

Figure 1. Principle components analysis for accessibility to cities, elevation, cropland cover, tree canopy cover, mean temperature, mean rainfall, and cloudiness for countries with greater than 50% cropland cover. Data from: Zander Venter

Summary

  • Tree canopy cover and cropland cover values are inverseley related
    • This makes sense, as cropland and forested areas are drastically different land uses
  • Tree cover and cropland cover show minimal correlation to average rainfall and average temperature
  • Elevation and cropland cover are negatively correlated
    • Possibly do to less suitable cropland at high elevations
  • Elevation and accessibility to cities are positively correlated
  • Cloudiness and tree canopy cover are positively correlated, possibly due to increased evapotranspiration.

item.title: Snowshoe Hare Abundance Analysis
item.description:
Introduction

The following analysis looks at the abundance and body weight statistics of snowshoe hare populations sampled by the Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research team in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest outside of Fairbanks, Alaska. Snowshoe hare weight by species sex was then compared and plotted (Figure 3). Summary statistics, including mean weight in grams, standard deviation, standard error, and sample size are provided for males and females (Table 1).

Necessary packages for this analysis include: tidyverse, janitor, kableExtra, and ggbeeswarm. All data analysis and visualization was produced using RStudio Version 1.2.1335.

Figure 1. Snowshoe Hare (Lepus americanus). Credit: The National Wildlife Federation

Figure 2. Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest map. Credit: PolarTec

Analysis

# Read in data:

snowshoes <- read_csv("showshoe_lter.csv")


# Wrangle data to select for sex, weight, and grid
# Tidy data to lowercase format, filtered for only confirmed males and females (omitted any data entries with ?)
# dropped all observations with 'na'
snowshoes_tidy2 <- snowshoes %>% 
  select(sex, weight, grid) %>% 
  mutate(grid = str_to_lower(grid)) %>% 
  mutate(sex = str_to_lower(sex)) %>% 
  filter(sex %in% c("m", "f")) %>% 
  mutate(sex = case_when(
    sex == "m" ~ "Male",
    sex == "f" ~ "Female"
  )) %>% 
  drop_na()
# Visualize data in beeswarm
# facet by sampling grid and separate by sex

ggplot(data = snowshoes_tidy2, aes(x = sex, y = weight)) +
  geom_beeswarm(aes(color = sex), size = 0.5, width = 0.2, show.legend = FALSE) +
  theme_bw() +
  facet_wrap(~grid) +
  labs(title = "Snowshoe Hare weight by sex for each sampling grid",
       subtitle = "1998 - 2012",
       x = "Sex",
       y = "Weight (g)")

Figure 3. Beeswarm plot showing weights of individual Snowshoe Hares across three sampling plots. Females are represented by the orange points, and Males are represented by the blue points. There is no clear visual difference in weight between males and females. Bonbs site refers to a site used to live trap hares. Bonmat refers to “Bonanza Mature” - a mature forest sampling site for hares. Bonrip refers to “Bonanza Riparian” - a flood zone and forested area sampling site. Abundance of hares in bonrip and bonbs greatly outnumberd abundance in bonmat. Data: Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research

Summary Statistics

Table 1. The table below shows summary statistics for Snowshoe Hare weight by sex, including mean weight in grams, standard deviation, standard error, and sample size. Female Hares have a slightly larger mean weight than males across all sites. Data: Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research

# Summary statistics

snowshoes_summary <- snowshoes_tidy2 %>%
  group_by(sex) %>% 
  summarize(mean_weight = mean(weight),
            sd_weight = sd(weight),
            standard_error = (sd(weight)/sqrt(length(weight))),
            sample_size = n()) %>% 
  mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 2)

snowshoes_summary %>% 
  kable(col.names = c("Sex", "Mean Weight (g)", "Standard Deviation", "Standard Error", "Sample Size")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F, position = "left") %>% 
  add_header_above(c("Snowshoe hare summary statistics by sex" = 5))
Snowshoe hare summary statistics by sex
Sex Mean Weight (g) Standard Deviation Standard Error Sample Size
Female 1365.16 347.45 8.94 1511
Male 1349.94 305.73 9.15 1117

Referances

Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14

item.title: Steelhead Migration Time Series Analysis
item.description:
Introduction

Steelhead passage through the Bonneville Dam in Oregon has been recorded on a daily basis from 1939 through September of 2019, and the data for these recordings has been provided by Columbia Basin Research at the University of Washington. This report explores time series data and visualizes daily, monthly, and annual counts of steelhead passage through the dam from 1939 to 2019 (Figures 2, 3, 4). These visualizations show temporal variation in steelhead passage through the years.

RStudio packages for this analysis include: tidyverse, janitor, lubridate, here, tsibble, and paletteer. All data analysis and visualization was produced using RStudio Version 1.2.1335.

Figure 1. Bonneville Dam, Oregon. Credit: US Army Corps of Engineers

# Read in and look at data

fish <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv") %>% 
  mutate(location = str_to_lower(location), parameter = str_to_lower(parameter)) %>% 
  rename("mmdd" = "mm-dd")

# names(fish)
# unique(fish$parameter)
# unique(fish$`mm-dd`)
# unique(fish$unit)
# unique(fish$datatype)
# unique(fish$value)
# Parse dates

fish_clean <- fish %>% 
  mutate(yearmonthday = str_c(year, mmdd, sep = "-")) %>% 
  mutate(year_mo_day = lubridate::parse_date_time(yearmonthday, "ydm")) %>% 
  mutate(day = day(year_mo_day)) %>% 
  mutate(month = month(year_mo_day, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  drop_na(value)
  

fish_dates <- fish %>% 
  mutate(mo_day = lubridate::parse_date_time(mmdd, "dm")) %>% 
  mutate(day = day(mo_day)) %>% 
  mutate(month = month(mo_day, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  select(-mo_day) 
# Plot time series of daily data
# fish_ts <- as_tsibble(fish_clean, key = value, index = month)

Daily variation in steelhead passage:

# daily plot through the years

ggplot(data = fish_clean, aes(x = year_mo_day, y = value)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue", size = 0.2) +
  labs(x = "year",
       y = "steelhead passing per day",
       title = "Daily steelhead passage through Bonneville Damn",
       subtitle = "1939-2019") +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,35000))

Figure 2. Daily observations for counts of steelhead passing through Bonneville Dam visualized. Daily counts appear to follow a consistant seasonality with the start of each year experiencing much lower counts than the middle of each year. Daily counts peak in 2009 and taper off to lower than 1940 daily values at the end of 2019. Data: Columbia Basin Research

Monthly variation in steelhead passage:

# Monthly passage through the years

fish_monthly <- fish_clean %>% 
  mutate(month_sep = yearmonth(year_mo_day)) %>% 
  group_by(month_sep, year, month) %>% 
  tally(value)

ggplot(data = fish_monthly, aes(x = year, y = n)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = month), show.legend = TRUE) +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_y_discrete(limits = c(0, 50000, 100000, 150000, 200000, 250000, 300000, 350000)) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c(1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2020)) +
  scale_color_paletteer_d("palettetown::rayquaza") +
  labs(x = "year",
       y = "monthly count",
       title = "Monthly steelhead counts through Bonneville Dam",
       subtitle = "1939-2019")

Figure 3. Monthly observations for counts of steelhead passing through Bonneville Dam visualized. Counts of steelhead passing are aggreggated by month from 1939 to 2019. Here we see the highest counts through the years are observed in July (yellow), August (brown), and September (gold), with hardly any observations in the winter months. Data: Columbia Basin Research

Annual variation in steelhead passage:

# Annual passage of fish through Bonneville Dam
fish_annual <- fish_clean %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(tot = sum(value))

ggplot(data = fish_annual, aes(x = year, y = tot)) +
  geom_line(color = "purple") +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_y_discrete(limits = c(0, 100000, 200000, 300000, 400000, 500000, 600000, 6550000)) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c(1940, 1960, 1980, 2000, 2020)) +
  labs(x = "year",
       y = "annual count",
       title = "Annual steelhead counts through Bonneville Dam",
       subtitle = "1939-2019")

Figure 4. Annual counts of steelhead passing through Bonneville Dam visualized by the purple line from 1939 to 2019. Counts remain below 400,000 steelheads annually, with the first big peak reaching around 380,000 in 1986. The largest peaks occur in 2001 and 2009, with 633,073 and 604,970 steelheads, respectively. Since 2009, annual steelhead passage through the dam has decreased, to a low of 77,195 in 2019. Data: Columbia Basin Research

item.title: Writing technical content in Academic
item.description:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you'll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.

Examples

Code

Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Math

Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.

Example math block:

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ 
\left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T 
\left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}
{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$

Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

renders as

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

Diagrams

Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}
```

renders as

classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:

- [x] Write math example
- [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
  • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Represent your data in tables:

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

renders as

First Header Second Header
Content Cell Content Cell
Content Cell Content Cell

Asides

Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% alert note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /alert %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Icons

Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.

Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:

{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal  
{{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python  
{{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R

renders as

Terminal
Python
R

item.title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Install Python and JupyterLab

Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.

Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook

Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:

mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
jupyter lab index.ipynb

The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.

Edit your post metadata

The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata ( front matter).

In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:

---
title: My post's title
date: 2019-09-01

# Put any other Academic metadata here...
---

Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.

To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post's folder.

For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.

Convert notebook to Markdown

jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.

Example

This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let's make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

Themes

Academic comes with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the sun/moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.

  • install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.
